title: Innocent Murmur -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Murmurs are the most common reason for pediatric cardiologist referral and evaluation. There are reports that up to 72% of children will have a murmur at some point during childhood and adolescence, and of these, some may stay present until adulthood, while others will resolve with time. This activity explains the proper evaluation and management of pediatric murmurs and reviews the most common benign murmurs found in pediatric patients. This activity highlights the role of the interprofessional team in caring for pediatric patients with murmurs.

title: Innocent Murmur -- Introduction
content: Historically, James Hope was one of the first physicians to recommend methods to recognize benign and innocent murmurs. In his 1942 textbook, Hope says “murmurs from these causes may easily be distinguished from that of valvular disease…” As the 20th century approached, it became more common knowledge among the medical community that healthy children and adolescents may have murmurs and gallops on physical exam that have no pathologic significance, especially in the asymptomatic patient. [1]

title: Innocent Murmur -- Etiology
content: The same physical and physiological principles responsible for pathologic heart murmurs are responsible for innocent heart murmurs. This principle is Turbulent Flow. Innocent murmurs are heard in settings of: Physiologically increased turbulent flow, as in relatively narrow ventricular outflow tracts, high cardiac output states like anemia, and false tendons in the left ventricle Relative vessel narrowing, as seen with vessels stretching during periods of rapid linear growth With lung expansion after birth as seen in peripheral pulmonic stenosis [2]

title: Innocent Murmur -- Epidemiology
content: Murmurs are the most common reason for pediatric cardiologist referral and evaluation. There are reports that up to 72% of children will have a murmur at some point during childhood and adolescence, and of these, some may stay present until adulthood, while others will resolve with time. [2] The concern of many practitioners stems from the anxiety of misdiagnosing a benign murmur in the setting of congenital heart disease (CHD). [2] The incidence of congenital heart disease in the general population is less than 1%, and of all the new murmurs referred to a pediatric cardiologist, less than 1% are a result of CHD. [1]

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical
content: Evaluation and identification of benign heart murmurs can be done primarily by thorough medical history and focused physical exam.

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- History
content: Neonates and Infants Conduct a perinatal, prenatal, as well as maternal history if paramount in the evaluation of newborns with heart murmurs. [1] Include: Maternal age, because advanced maternal age is associated with an increased risk of all heart defects. History of maternal infections, such as TORCH, with a special focus on rubella infection in the first trimester given its high association with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), pulmonary valve abnormalities, peripheral pulmonary stenosis, and ventricular septal defects (VSD). Maternal diabetes mellitus is also of importance due to its association with asymmetric hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- History
content: Postnatal history is just as important, and should focus on feeding difficulties (sweating while feeding), failure to thrive, cyanosis during feeding or activity, respiratory symptoms (tachypnea and increased work of breathing). [1]

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- History
content: Note that grade 2/6 and louder murmurs in the first 24 hours of life are more likely to have an underlying cardiac disease, while lower pitch murmurs in the first, second, or third day of life could be related to changes in pulmonary vascular resistance, a closing PDA, and/or physiological tricuspid regurgitation. [2]

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- History
content: In older children and adolescents the above still holds true, however special attention to activity level should be paid. Any patient with a new murmur and decreased activity level, or worsening exercise tolerance (especially compared to peers), or complaints of shortness of breath, chest pain or syncope on exertion should raise major concerns for underlying cardiac pathology. [1] When assessing exercise tolerance, it is important to do so with an age-appropriate approach. [3]

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- General
content: As with any other patient, it is always important to start the examination of a child who has a murmur by general inspection and not directly with auscultation. The examiner should pay close attention for any dysmorphic features, color changes, respiratory effort, or other congenital anomalies. [1]

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Vital Signs
content: Every patient should have a complete set of vital signs, including blood pressure (BP). [1] If there is already a concern for underlying cardiac disease, then 4-limb blood pressure would be highly recommended. Look for any discrepancies in upper and lower limb blood pressures as this could rule-out in aortic coarctation. Remember that lower limb BP is generally 10 to 20 mm Hg higher than upper limb, and if the upper limb BP is higher, then coarctation needs to be ruled out. [1]

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Vital Signs
content: Oxygen saturation is also important. Cyanotic heart lesions may not present at birth, especially ductal-dependent lesions or Tetralogy of Fallot. If intra/extra-cardiac shunting is suspected then upper and lower extremity pulse oximetry should be measured. [3]

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Palpation
content: Palpation of the distal pulses should always be done in cardiac patients. [1] The quality and timing of the pulses can be very important in physical finding associated with certain cardiac lesions. In benign murmurs, the clinicians should be able to feel equal and normal pulses throughout, keeping in mind that physiologically, the femoral pulses should be felt earlier than the brachial pulses in an otherwise normal patient.

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Palpation
content: Palpation of the chest is also important as it can give you information of cardiomegaly due to a displaced point of maximal impulse (PMI) or a hyperdynamic precordium. [1] Thrills are also important as they will help grade any murmurs (discussed later).

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Palpation
content: Lastly, palpation of the abdomen is crucial. The abdominal exam may give the examiner insight into the organs of the patient, for example,  situs inversus as well as findings of congestive heart failure such as hepatomegaly. [2]

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Auscultation
content: The auscultatory examination should always be done systematically. The 4 general areas of the cardiac exam (aortic, pulmonary, tricuspid, and mitral) should be examined first, followed by areas of radiation such as the neck, axilla, and back. [1] Each heart sound should be assessed independently for any abnormalities, clicks, extra sounds, and finally the presence of murmurs. Special note should be made to the following characteristics of any murmur:

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Auscultation
content: Timing : Systolic versus diastolic. Note than holosystolic/pansystolic murmurs are most often associated with cardiac lesions such as VSD. Purely diastolic murmurs are by definition always pathologic until proven otherwise by echocardiogram or cardiac cath. [1] Intensity : Grading scale of 1 to 6. Note that a specialist should evaluate any murmur with a grade higher than 3 and consider it pathologic until proven otherwise. [1] Grade 1 is a sound softer than the heart sounds Grade 2 is a sound as loud as the heart sounds Grade 3 is louder the heart sounds Grade 4 is a grade 3 sound plus presence of a palpable thrill Grade 5 is a very loud sound heard with stethoscope barely on the chest Grade 6 is a very loud sound heard with the stethoscope just off the surface of the chest [1] Location : Location of the murmur on the chest by auscultatory regions mentioned above. The region where the murmur is heard the loudest should be specified here. [1]

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Auscultation
content: Quality : Harsh, blowing, musical, and squeaky. Benign murmurs are most often blowing or musical in quality. [1] Pitch : Low, Medium, or High. High pitched murmurs are most often pathologic. Most benign murmurs have a low-soft pitch vibratory quality. [1]

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Auscultation
content: Radiation : Murmurs are often heard loudest at one region and softer in others. Areas to which murmurs radiate to should be of note. Specifically radiation to unilateral axillae like in mitral regurgitation, or radiation to neck as in aortic stenosis. [1] Some benign murmurs may also radiate like pulmonary flow murmurs which radiate to the back or peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis which radiate to bilateral axillary lines. [3]

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Auscultation
content: Response to Maneuvers : Pathologic murmurs, especially those of valvular origin will not change in intensity with maneuvers. [1] Other pathologic murmurs such as that from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may change, but that will not be discussed in this article.

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Auscultation
content: Benign murmurs often do change significantly with position. Specifically of note is the stills/flow murmur which is loudest while the patient is supine given the decrease in afterload seen in this position. [3] Venous hum murmurs also change but in the opposite manner. Venous hums are best heard with the patient sitting up and will most often completely disappear with the patient in the supine position. [3]

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Auscultation
content: One auscultatory finding to keep in mind is that of a flow murmur in the presence of a widely-fixed split S2. The wide-fixed split second heart sound is the most consistent finding of an ASD even without the presence of a systolic ejection murmur.

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Systolic Ejection Murmurs
content: Stills Murmur [3] Most common; usually disappears by adolescence but can persist into adulthood Musical, soft, vibratory low-pitched systolic ejection murmur heard best over left lower sternal border and apex. Grade 1 to 3/6. Loudest when supine. No radiation. Innocent Pulmonary Flow Murmur [3] Second most common, Soft, blowing, low-pitched systolic ejection murmur, grade 1 to 3/6, usually heard best over the left upper sternal border and may radiate to the back and axilla. Peripheral Pulmonary Artery Stenosis [3] Most commonly in the first year of life, especially in premature babies Short, soft, mid-systolic ejection murmur, grade 1 to 2/6, heard best over right/left upper sternal border with radiation to the axilla. Arterial Supraclavicular Murmur [3] Most commonly seen in late childhood and early adolescence Brief, low-pitched murmur, grade 1 to 3/6, best hear in supraclavicular fossa and may radiate to the neck.

title: Innocent Murmur -- History and Physical -- Benign Continuous Murmurs
content: Venous Hum [3] Most common continuous benign murmur, most often seen between 2 to 8 years of life Soft, whirling, low-pitched murmur, grade 1 to 3/6, heard best in high right sternal border and the right infraclavicular area in the upright position. Murmur does not radiate, disappears completely when supine or when patient extends the neck and turns to the right. Mammary Souffle [3] Least common, usually heard primarily in young adult women, especially when pregnant or lactating. Soft, blowing, high-pitched systolic murmur, grade 1 to 2/6, heard best over anterior chest, specifically over the breasts, softer when upright or with high stethoscope pressure.

title: Innocent Murmur -- Evaluation
content: If a pathologic murmur is suspected, referral to a cardiologist is warranted. [2] Studies have shown that chest x-rays and electrocardiograms have little diagnostic value compared to a specialist’s exam. [3] If a cardiologist remains concerned after his/her exam, the most likely next step would be an echocardiogram for anatomic visualization. [7] [8]

title: Innocent Murmur -- Treatment / Management
content: Benign murmurs tend to resolve with time, though some may still progress onto adulthood never showing any symptoms. When a murmur is deemed benign, there is no need for further clinical monitoring and the patient should live a healthy normal life. It is only important to document such findings as to prevent further stress and unnecessary work-up in the future. It should be noted that no activity restrictions or endocardial prophylaxis are needed as to not deprive the child/patient of any sports or work participation.

title: Innocent Murmur -- Pearls and Other Issues
content: The medical community should understand the personal and familial anxiety that a murmur classification brings. In the setting of such benign findings, clinicians should strive for better nomenclature of such benign findings as to not increase anxiety and to decrease unnecessary investigation by perhaps renaming “benign murmurs” as innocent flow sounds or benign heart sounds. This might ease the minds of our patients’ and their families and would allow them to participate in everyday activities without impending concerns of possible underlying heart disease in addition to reducing health care costs.

title: Innocent Murmur -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: Auscultation is not a very sensitive technique to make a diagnosis of an innocent murmur. When a murmur is detected on a routine physical exam, a thorough patient exam is necessary. The decision to obtain an echo depends on physical findings and patient symptoms. In general, when a patient is designated to have an innocent murmur, close follow up is required to ensure that the murmur either disappears or that no cardiac symptoms develop. [8] [9]
